text.p: - Alexander Rutskoi, former vice-president and President Boris Yeltsin's arch-rival, staged a political comeback at local elections in his native region of Kursk where he reaped a vote of protest against recent political muddle in the Kremlin.
- Moscow puts pressure on Belorussian President Alexander Lukashenko to steer him away from using force in a conflict with parliament.

- The police are trying to unearth compromising materials against the head of the Central Bank Sergei Dubinin, which could be a retaliation attempt by a string of shaky commercial banks with which he has been strict.
- Andrei Kostin, the new head of Russia's biggest bank Vnesheconombank, says he wants an agreement with foreign creditors before the end of 1996.
- General Alexander Lebed is mulling the possibility of returning to high politics through governorial elections in his native Tula region.
- Viktor Samsonov, reappointed head of the armed forces' General Staff, says the situation there is "alarming, almost critical and hard to control, but stable".
- A meeting between President Boris Yeltsin and Duma speaker Gennady Seleznyov could mean the Communists are being drawn into the political establishment.
- Monday's police raid on a Moscow commercial bank in search of materials against the Central Bank head Dubinin is only one episode in a string of attempts to compromise him.

- Presidential chief-of-staff Anatoly Chubais's grip on Russia's financial resources in case of an early presidential election could prompt his opponent to rely heavily on unconstitutional methods and the army.
- Equal partnership has not yet superceded the balance of power of the cold war era, says Russian Foreign Minister Evgeny Primakov.
- Only 16 percent of Russia's companies and enterprises pay taxes on time and in full.
- The remains of a German wartime fighter plane shot down in 1941 together with its four crew were found buried in the ground near Moscow on Sunday.
